headline.main: OUR WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENCE.; CROWDS IN THE HOTELS THE COMING SESSION OF CONGRESS INDICATIONS OF THE POPULAR MIND GEN. SCOTT AND THE WAR THE SPEAKERSHIP, ETC.

docs.lead_paragraph: The hotels of Washington are crowded with a promiscuous throng of soldiers and politicians, eager for military and civic appointments. The epaulets, however, considerably predominate, and the legiti- mate inference is that genuine patriotism is in at least equal proportion to the cheap article which passes current in "piping times of peace."

headline.main: AFFAIRS ACROSS THE POTOMAC.; HIGHLY IMPORTANT FROM THE ENEMY-- STATEMENTS MADE BY A SOUTH CAROLINA PRISONER-- CONDITION AND PROSPECTS OF THE REBEL TROOPS AT FAIRFAX, CENTREVILLE, AND MANASSAS JUNCTION.

docs.lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning, the pickets of one of the Connecticut Regiments succeeded in arresting a private of the First South Carolina Volunteers, who had strayed beyond his own lines, in pursuit

docs.snippet: It is wonderful how much men will undergo cheerfully, without a murmur, when the spiritual spring is touched when they find some principle, some idea that is above materiality to labor for.

headline.main: AFFAIRS AT CAMP HAMILTON.; THE SPIRIT OF THE MEN-- BLACK SHEEP-- DAILY DUTIES-- A WELL-MERITED REWARD-- SANITARY MATTERS.

docs.lead_paragraph: It is wonderful how much men will undergo cheerfully, without a murmur, when the spiritual spring is touched when they find some principle, some idea that is above materiality to labor for.

docs.snippet: The military element is being superseded to a large extent by the civil. Members of Congress are arriving in great numbers, and in their retinues bring a host of aspirants for positions in the House.

headline.main: THE GREAT REBELLION.; Important News From Washington and Vicinity. An Advance of the National Forces Again Talked of. How They Will Celebrate the Glorious Fourth. ANOTHER SKIRMISH WITH REBEL SCOUTS. The Movements and Intentions of Beauregard. He Still Intends to Maren on the Capital. Preparations for the Meeting of Congress. THE CONTEST FOR THE SPEAKERSHIP. The Forward Movement at Fortress Monroe. Affairs in Maryland and Western Virginia. THE SPEAKERSHIP. CLERK OF THE SENATE. A FORWARD MOVEMENT. A CULINARY BUREAU. GEN. MCDOWELL NOT SUPERSEDED. THE NEW JERSEY TROOPS. THE SIXTY-NINTH's INTRENCHMENTS. ENCAMPMENTS. A DESERVED PROMOTION. AFFAIRS IN BALTIMORE. DISTRICT VOLUNTEERS. REBEL PROMOTIONS. THE CONFEDERATE LOAN. WHAT A LADY REPORTS. HOW INFORMATION IS CONVEYED. MORE TROOPS ARRIVED. THE ADVANCE GUARD. PATIENTS IN THE HOSPITAL. MARCHING ORDERS. PRISONERS IN THE CITY JAIL. ANOTHER SKIRMISH. VISITORS. THE SEVENTY-FIRST REGIMENT. DRUMMER DROWNED. DISORDERLY SOLDIERS. REVIEWS. COLDER WEATHER. THE MESSAGE. HEALTH OF THE ARMY. DISPATCH

docs.lead_paragraph: The military element is being superseded to a large extent by the civil. Members of Congress are arriving in great numbers, and in their retinues bring a host of aspirants for positions in the House.

docs.snippet: A correspondent of the Atlantic (Ga.) Confederacy, gives an intersting account of the contemplated work which lies before Gen. WISE in Northwest Virginia. According to this correspondent, who writes from Richmond on the 10th inst., Gen. WISE
